Veliza is a Voyant adapt
ation of the famous Eliza program written by Joseph Weizenbaum in 1966 and
it provides a mechanism for automated dialogue (there's more information in
abindex-counter="4">Veliza documentation). Eliza was meant as a parody of a
Rogerian psychotherapist, but wouldn't it be interesting to experiment with a ch
atbot that could help dialogue with a corpus of texts? Veliza's not there yet, b
ut she's learning, and in this notebook we'll explain a bit more about how she l

earns.

Veliza is designed to dialgue with a particular corpus, so we'l
l start by loading a reference to a (built-in) corpus of works by Jane Aust
en. Once we have the corpus, we can use it to embed an instance of Veliza into o
ur notebook, while providing an initial message (feel free to add your own messa
ges in the code or in the embedded tool).
Veliza has responded to our declaration of love, but it's not very interestin
g. But we can change that. You'll notice that there's a script editor that can b
e opened to the right of the panel. By default the current Veliza script will be
shown and can be edited. However, editing it there in place means that we can't

describe what we're trying to accomplish, as we can here in Spiral.

Great! Not the most spectacular example of artificial intelligence, but maybe
it would surprise someone, especially if they happen to be working with the Aus

ten corpus.

Veliza allows us to not only capture and reuse words from the
incoming message (typed by the user or sent from the text), it also has some spe
cial syntax to embed certain Voyant tools. Let's see an example:
p;reasmb: You want to see a concordance of " (2) " ? <!-- {"tool": "Contexts"
his will cause Veliza to recognize the word "concordance" followed by "of the wo
rd", followed by a word and then perhaps others, as in the sentence "Show me a c
oncordance of the word love." If that sentence matches, then we see the output "
You want to see a concordance of " (2) " ?" The (2) is a reference to the s
econd asterisk in our rule, the word following "of the word". The HTML comment <
for the tool to use, dimensions of the window and our matched word as a query.</
